Article Title: Thousands flock to Bethlehem to revive Christmas spirit after 2 years of war in Gaza
Article Text:
People gather next to the Christmas tree at Manger Square in Bethlehem (Pictur credit: AP)

Hamas Refuses To End Gaza Fight? Netanyahu Gets Chilling Warning | ‚Äò3rd INTIFADA Would Break Out‚Äô





BETHLEHEM: Thousands of people flocked to Bethlehem‚Äôs Manger Square on Christmas Eve as families heralded a much-needed boost of holiday spirit. The giant Christmas tree that was absent during the Israel-Hamas war returned Wednesday, overlooking a parade of scouts playing songs on bagpipes.The city where Christians believe Jesus was born cancelled Christmas celebrations for the past two years. Manger Square had instead featured a nativity scene of baby Jesus surrounded by rubble and barbed wire in homage to the situation in Gaza. Cardinal Pierbattista Pizzaballa, top Catholic leader in the Holy Land, kicked off this year‚Äôs celebrations during the traditional procession from Jerusalem to Bethlehem, calling for ‚Äúa Christmas full of light‚Äù.Arriving in Manger Square, Pizzaballa said he came bearing greetings from Gaza‚Äôs tiny Christian community, where he held a pre-Christmas Mass on Sunday. Among the devastation, he saw a desire to rebuild.‚ÄúWe, all together, we decide to be the light, and the light of Bethlehem is the light of the world,‚Äù he told thousands of people, Christian and Muslim.Despite the holiday cheer, the impact of the war in the Israeli-occupied West Bank is acute, especially in Bethlehem, where around 80% of the Muslim-majority city‚Äôs residents depend upon tourism-related businesses.The vast majority of people celebrating were residents, with a handful of foreigners. Some residents said they are starting to see signs of change as tourism slowly returns. ‚ÄúToday is a day of joy, a day of hope, beginning of the return of normal life here,‚Äù said Bethlehem resident Georgette Jackaman, a tour guide who has not worked in more than two years.A visitor from France, Mona Riewer, said ‚ÄúI came because I wanted to better understand what people in Palestine are going through, and you can sense people have been through a very hard time.‚Äù Fadi Zoughbi, who previously worked overseeing logistics for tour groups, said his children were ecstatic to see marching bands streaming through the streets.Irene Kirmiz, who grew up in Bethlehem and now lives in Ramallah, said the scout parade is among her favourite Christmas traditions. Her daughter, 15, plays the tenor drum with the Ramallah scouts. Her family had to wake up at 5am to arrive in time for the parade and waited upwards of three hours at Israeli checkpoints. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs very emotional seeing people trying to bounce back, trying to celebrate peace and love.‚Äù
Article Summary: Cardinal Pierbattista Pizzaballa, top Catholic leader in the Holy Land, kicked off this year‚Äôs celebrations during the traditional procession from Jerusalem to Bethlehem. Manger Square had instead featured a nativity scene of baby Jesus surrounded by rubble and barbed wire in homage to the situation in Gaza. Despite the holiday cheer, the impact of the war in the Israeli-occupied West Bank is acute.

Article Title: Bangladesh: Zia‚Äôs son returns home today, BNP banking on him to tide through polls
Article Text:
File photo: Tarique Rahman, son of former PM Khaleda Zia (Picture credit: AP)

Osman Hadi's Brother Accuses Yunus Regime Of Murder Plot To Defer Bangladesh Polls Scheduled in Feb





DHAKA: Tarique Rahman, former PM Khaleda Zia‚Äôs son and BNP‚Äôs heir apparent, returns to Bangladesh Thursday along with his family, ending over 17 years of self-exile. On the eve of his return, the country‚Äôs largest political party described the moment as ‚Äúboth politically significant and emotionally charged. ‚ÄùHis return, along with wife Zubaida and daughter Zaima, comes less than two months before the parliamentary elections and BNP sources said his presence in campaigns as its star leader will help boost its prospects and its workers‚Äô morale.BNP is facing the challenge of growing popularity of the coalition led by the country‚Äôs largest Islamist party Jamaat-e-Islami, especially among the youth. To mark his return, BNP has organised a reception in the outskirts of Dhaka, for which the party expects thousands to gather.Rahman was detained by the 2007-2008 military-backed caretaker govt, and he went to Britain after the regime released him and has been living in London since then. He had faced multiple criminal convictions, including a case related to a plot to assassinate Hasina. He was, however, acquitted of all charges after Hasina‚Äôs removal.Though he has been leading the party from abroad, his return now comes as he prepares to take a more direct role in party affairs, sources said.
Article Summary: Tarique Rahman, former PM Khaleda Zia‚Äôs son, returns to Bangladesh along with his family, ending over 17 years of self-exile. Rahman was detained by the 2007-2008 military-backed caretaker govt, and he went to Britain after the regime released him and has been living in London since then.

Article Title: Will take responsibility of kin of lynched Hindu worker: Dhaka
Article Text:
Bangladesh Education Adviser CR Abrar meets Rabilal Das, father of Dipu Chanrda Das, and expresses his condolences, in Mymensingh

Yunus Govt Takes Responsibility Of Dipu Das Family After India Erupts Over Hindu Man's Lynching





Facing criticism from different quarters and international condemnation over targetting of minority communities, the Muhammad Yunus-led interim govt has announced the state will take responsibility of the family of the Hindu worker - Dipu Chandra Das - who was lynched on blasphemy charges last week and asserted it is taking "the highest efforts for the protection of minorities".The killing of Das in Mymensigh, amid a series of attacks on Hindus since the Sheikh Hasina govt's collapse last year and Yunus taking charge as chief adviser, has further strained India-Bangladesh ties. On behalf of the interim govt, education adviser C R Abrar, after visiting Das's family on Tuesday, announced the state will take responsibility of the family, providing it financial as well as welfare assistance.On Wednesday, the chief adviser's office said the assistance will be provided to the family by authorities in the "coming period". "We have strongly condemned this (the lynching) and 12 people have been arrested, so far, on the basis of videos. We are giving the highest efforts for the protection of minority," chief adviser's press secretary Shafiqul Alam told reporters.The govt has said allegations, rumours, or differences of belief can never excuse violence, and no individual has the right to take the law into their own hands."We remain fully committed to ensuring the safety, dignity, and equal protection of all citizens, regardless of religion, ethnicity, or background," the government added.
Article Summary: Dipu Chandra Das, a Hindu worker, was lynched on blasphemy charges last week. The killing has further strained India-Bangladesh ties. Muhammad Yunus-led interim govt has announced the state will take responsibility of the family.

Article Title: Russia-Ukraine war: Zelensky says open to demilitarised zone in Donetsk to reach peace deal
Article Text:
File photo: Ukraine's President Zelensky

Putin Smirks As Zelensky Blinks, Offers Concessions To Moscow In New 20-Point Peace Plan





KYIV: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine told reporters on Tuesday that he was ready to pull his troops back from areas of the eastern Donetsk region still under Kyiv‚Äôs control and turn them into a demilitarized zone as part of a possible peace deal with Moscow.The offer was the closest Zelensky has come to addressing the thorny territorial disputes in Donetsk that have repeatedly derailed peace talks, signalling his willingness to compromise after weeks of US-mediated negotiations.But the proposal also hinted at the significant gaps that remain between Ukraine and Russia. Zelensky‚Äôs offer of a demilitarized zone came with a condition: Russia would have to pull its forces from an equivalent stretch of land in Donetsk. So far, the Kremlin has given no indication that it is willing to accept anything less than full control over the region.The proposal forms part of a revised 20-point peace plan that was drawn up by Ukraine and the US in the past few weeks and that Zelensky presented to reporters in Kyiv on Tuesday. The blueprint covers a broad range of issues, from potential territorial arrangements to the security guarantees Ukraine wants to prevent future Russian aggression, as well as plans to rebuild the war-ravaged nation.Zelensky portrayed the plan as Ukraine‚Äôs best effort to end the war and said it was now up to Russia to decide how to respond.The Ukrainian leader said the various points in the plan ‚Äúlargely reflect the joint Ukrainian American position.‚Äù But Ukraine and Washington did not reach an agreement on two sticking points: the fate of Ukrainian-held territory in Donetsk and control of a major nuclear plant currently occupied by Russia. On the second point, Ukraine offered to manage the plant jointly with the US as a form of compromise.Ukraine‚Äôs proposed concessions, even if accepted in full by the US, are likely to be rejected by Moscow. The Kremlin has insisted that its primary goal is a full military takeover of Donetsk and has dismissed any notion of returning the nuclear plant to Ukrainian control.The Kremlin said President Putin had been briefed about the negotiations. ‚ÄúWe aim to formulate our future stance and resume our contacts shortly,‚Äù Kremlin spokesperson Dmitry Peskov said Wednesday. Zelensky voiced cautious optimism that Moscow would not openly rebuff the new proposal for fear of angering President Trump.
Article Summary: Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelensky offered to pull his troops back from areas of the eastern Donetsk region still under Kyiv‚Äôs control as part of a possible peace deal with Moscow. The offer of a demilitarized zone came with a condition: Russia would have to pull its forces from an equivalent stretch of land in Donetsk.

Article Title: Bangladesh unrest: Section within Yunus government got activist Hadi killed, says his brother
Article Text:
File photo

Yunus Govt Takes Responsibility Of Dipu Das Family After India Erupts Over Hindu Man's Lynching

Zia‚Äôs son was first to link Hadi‚Äôs killing to ‚Äòconspiracy‚Äô





DHAKA: Slain anti-India activist Sharif Osman Hadi‚Äôs brother Omar has accused a section within the Muhammad Yunus-led interim Bangladesh govt of orchestrating the killing to derail the Feb 12 national election and warned of a Sheikh Hasina-like fate if Osman‚Äôs attackers are not tried quickly.‚ÄúIt is you who had Osman Hadi killed, and now you are trying to foil the election by using this as an issue,‚Äù Omar said. ‚ÄúYou too will be compelled to flee Bangladesh one day if justice for Osman is not served. He always wanted the election to be held in Feb,‚Äù Omar said during a programme organised by Osman‚Äôs party Inqilab Moncho in Dhaka Tuesday.Ensure the trial of the killers quickly so that the election environment is not hindered, said Omar as he accused the govt of failing to present any visible progress before the people.Inqilab Moncho member secretary Abdullah Al Jaber reiterated the ultimatum of 30 working days given to the govt to identify and arrest the attackers. Till recently, a large section in Bangladesh pinned the blame for the assassination of Osman on New Delhi, leading to large-scale anti-India protests outside Indian high commission in Dhaka, and its assistant high commissions in Khulna, Rajshahi and Chittagong, where a stone-pelting mob precariously came close to the diplomat‚Äôs residence despite presence of Bangladeshi security personnel.Omar‚Äôs remarks are significant also because of the efforts the Yunus-led interim administration to align itself with his supporters. The govt flew the Islamic hardliner to Singapore for treatment for a critical gunshot injury to the head, arranged for a massive memorial service following his death on Dec 18 and allocated a grave beside the mausoleum of Bangladesh‚Äôs national poet Kazi Nazrul Islam.It was former PM Khaleda Zia‚Äôs son and BNP acting chairperson Tarique Rahman who had first linked the Osman‚Äôs killing to a ‚Äúconspiracy to get the poll postponed‚Äù. As it happens, Tarique, who has been living in exile in the UK for over 17 years, is scheduled to reach Dhaka on Thursday.
Article Summary: Sharif Osman Hadi‚Äôs brother Omar has accused a section within the Muhammad Yunus-led interim Bangladesh govt of orchestrating the killing. Omar warned of a Sheikh Hasina-like fate if Osman's attackers are not tried quickly.

Article Title: Don't break our family: Indian-origin man in New Zealand shocked to learn his 5-year-old autistic child could be deported
Article Text:
New Zealand India FTA Sparks Coalition Rift As PM Christopher Luxon Backs Deal, NZ First Rejects It

Bur rules are rules...





An Indian -origin healthcare worker in New Zealand, Nithin Mankeel, received the greatest shock of his life when he learned that his five-year-old son could not be allowed legally in the country as he is autistic. Mankeel moved to New Zealand from India in January 2024, followed by his wife and son later that year.He works as an elder care nurse, and his wife Aparna Jayandhan Geetha works as a senior healthcare assistant. Mankeel, whose job is on Tier 1 of INZ's Green List, applied for the straight-to-residence pathway, listing his family members as secondary applicants.The administration sought to know about his son Aidhan's delayed speech abilities and was then told that all their visas would be declined unless he withdrew Aidhan's name and applied separately for a different visa category.RNZ reported that Mankeel did that and his and his wife's visas were approved but their son's was not and this means the five-year-old could be deported."I was really, really shocked," Mankeel said."It's really heartbreaking. I don't know how, mentally, I can cope, if that's going to happen," he said.INZ deputy chief operating officer Jeannie Melville said applicants assessed as likely to impose significant costs on health and education services could not be granted a waiver, "regardless of family circumstances or occupation"."We understand the challenges faced by Mr Mankeel and his family; however, immigration health requirements are very specific and can only be waived through ministerial intervention. The granting of residence to Mr Mankeel and his wife was based on the critical need for healthcare professionals in New Zealand, as reflected by their inclusion in Tier 1 of the Green List. All secondary applicants must still meet the health criteria for their visa category," she said.Meanwhile, Mankeel explained why he can't go back to India now. "I don't have any licence to practise in India because we cancelled that and got the registration here. We left everything and came [here]," he said."We are living full of fear but I'm getting so much support from many, many different communities," he said. "I'm getting weaker day by day but I'm getting all this support, I'm getting the energy to push forward. We are just praying and hoping for the best."
Article Summary: Nithin Mankeel moved to New Zealand from India in January 2024, followed by his wife and son later that year. He works as an elder care nurse, and his wife Aparna Jayandhan Geetha works as a senior healthcare assistant. His job is on Tier 1 of INZ's Green List, listing his family members as secondary applicants.

Article Title: Poll shock: Trump‚Äôs longtime critic Jerome Powell is more popular than the president
Article Text:
What the poll reveals about Trump and Powell



Trump trails despite strong Republican support



A long-running clash



Rates, policy and public moments





Jerome Powell has emerged as the most popular figure among senior US leaders, according to a new national survey. The finding places him ahead of President Donald Trump , whose approval rating remains near historic lows.The results come from a Gallup national poll conducted in early December 2025. The survey was carried out between December 1 and 15 and included roughly 1,000 US adults. It measured job approval for 13 major political and institutional figures.Gallup found that Powell holds a 44% job-approval rating, the highest of any figure tested in the survey. Trump‚Äôs approval rating stood at 36%, which Gallup described as a new low for his second term and only slightly above his all-time low of 34% recorded in 2021.Only two figures crossed the 40% threshold. Powell ranked first, followed by Secretary of State Marco Rubio, who registered a 41% approval rating. All other leaders included in the poll remained below that level.The survey shows that Trump‚Äôs approval remains sharply polarised along partisan lines. About 89% of Republicans approve of his performance, while support among independents is far lower and approval among Democrats is near zero.This divide continues to pull the president‚Äôs overall rating into the mid-30s.Powell‚Äôs numbers also reflect partisan division. While his 44% approval does not represent majority support, it remains the strongest net rating among all the figures tested in the poll.The result is notable given Trump‚Äôs repeated and public attacks on Powell throughout 2025. The president has criticised the Fed chair over interest-rate policy, called him a ‚Äúloser,‚Äù and pressed the central bank to cut rates more aggressively to support economic growth.Trump has also suggested that Powell should resign and has openly weighed replacing him when his term as Fed chair ends in May 2026, despite having nominated Powell to the position during his first term.The Federal Reserve has cut interest rates three times this year as it seeks to support a slowing economy. The most recent cut, announced in December, lowered the benchmark rate by 0.25 percentage points to a target range of 3.5% to 3.75%.Tensions between the two men have also played out publicly. In July, Powell corrected Trump during a visit to the Federal Reserve after the president misstated renovation costs at the Fed‚Äôs headquarters, an exchange that drew widespread attention.Gallup noted that no leader in the survey approached 50% approval, highlighting a broader mood of dissatisfaction with national leadership. The poll measures job approval rather than personal favourability or voting intent and reflects deep partisan divides across nearly all figures tested.
Article Summary: Gallup found that Powell holds a 44% job-approval rating, the highest of any figure tested in the survey. Trump‚Äôs approval rating stood at 36%, which Gallup described as a new low for his second term. The president has criticised the Fed chair over interest-rate policy.

Article Title: Pennsylvania nursing home blast: Facility rated one star and ‚Äòmuch below average‚Äô in health inspections
Article Text:
Deadly Blast Rocks Pennsylvania; Nursing Home Destroyed As Explosion Causes Multiple Casualties





The Silver Lake Nursing Home, the site of a devastating explosion on Tuesday, had an overall rating of one star on Medicare‚Äôs federal Care Compare system, indicating its health inspections are considered ‚Äúmuch below average. ‚ÄùThe rating has raised questions about the facility‚Äôs safety and care standards, especially following the blast, which trapped many residents under debris. The explosion is suspected to have been caused by a gas leak, and numerous rescue teams were on site to assist.The Medicare star system evaluates nursing homes across three categories: health inspections, staffing, and quality measures. Silver Lake scores particularly poorly in health inspections, receiving only one star. Inspectors found multiple deficiencies in care and compliance with state and federal standards.The most recent health inspection in the nursing home took place in September 2024. The facility passed fire safety and emergency preparedness checks, the low inspection score suggests there were significant issues in resident care, medication management, or overall safety compliance. The poor ranking indicates that Silver Lake performs far below the national average for nursing homes of similar size and scope.Medicare‚Äôs five-star system is designed to help families and caregivers compare facilities when making decisions about care. A one-star rating, particularly in health inspections, signals potential risks to residents and areas in urgent need of improvement. The rating does not capture every aspect of care, but it shows significant concerns about regulatory compliance and day-to-day operations.The importance of rating comes into play after the nursing home suffered a major explosion, which trapped residents and forced emergency crews to conduct large-scale evacuations. The exact cause of the blast is still under investigation, but the facility‚Äôs low health inspection score has raised questions about its readiness for emergencies and its overall ability to protect residents.
Article Summary: Silver Lake Nursing Home had an overall rating of one star on Medicare‚Äôs federal Care Compare system. A one-star rating signals potential risks to residents and areas in urgent need of improvement. The rating does not capture every aspect of care, but shows significant concerns about regulatory compliance and day-to-day operations.

Article Title: From civil rights to clickbait: Dave Chappelle‚Äôs take on Charlie Kirk comparison with Martin Luther King Jr
Article Text:
Charlie Kirk's KILLER In Court; Tyler Robinson Defiant, Shows No Remorse | Dramatic Scenes On Cam





Comedian Dave Chappelle has forcefully rejected a comparison between conservative commentator Charlie Kirk and civil rights icon Martin Luther King Jr, calling the idea exaggerated and fundamentally misguided.In a clip circulating widely on social media, Chappelle responded to claims that Kirk represents a modern equivalent of Dr King. His verdict was blunt, arguing that the comparison stretches credibility far beyond breaking point.Chappelle dismissed the analogy almost immediately, saying that while both figures are well known, the similarities effectively end there. He acknowledged that both men have faced violence, but stressed that shared notoriety or controversy does not place them on the same moral or historical footing.According to Chappelle, equating a digital-era political influencer with a leader of a mass civil rights movement misunderstands what made Dr King significant. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a reach,‚Äù he said, a phrase commonly used to describe an argument that is forced or unsupported by reality.At the heart of Chappelle‚Äôs critique was the difference between activism shaped by history and activism shaped by algorithms. He described Kirk primarily as an internet personality whose influence depends on provoking reactions and driving engagement online.Chappelle argued that modern online figures often rely on controversy to remain visible, because outrage fuels clicks, views and shares. That dynamic, he suggested, is fundamentally incompatible with the kind of leadership embodied by Dr King, whose work was rooted in grassroots organising, moral persuasion and sustained collective action.To underline the contrast, Chappelle jokingly imagined Dr King adopting the language of modern content creators, urging audiences to ‚Äúsubscribe‚Äù or ‚Äúchange my mind‚Äù, a comparison that drew laughter while reinforcing his point about the absurdity of the analogy.ID@undefinedCaption not available.The episode highlights a broader cultural tension over how historical legacies are invoked in today‚Äôs political debates. As social media blurs the line between activism, commentary and entertainment, comparisons to figures such as Martin Luther King Jr increasingly provoke backlash.For Chappelle, the line remains clear. Moral leadership forged in the struggle for civil rights, he suggests, cannot be reduced to viral moments or engagement metrics. In his view, moving ‚Äúfrom civil rights to clickbait‚Äù is precisely where such comparisons go wrong.
Article Summary: Comedian Dave Chappelle has forcefully rejected a comparison between conservative commentator Charlie Kirk and civil rights icon Martin Luther King Jr. He described Kirk primarily as an internet personality whose influence depends on provoking reactions and driving engagement online. The episode highlights a broader cultural tension over how historical legacies are invoked in political debates.

Article Title: Saudi Arabia sees rare snowfall after 30 years, desert mountains turn into winter wonderland
Article Text:
Rare snowfall blankets Saudi Arabia after 30 years, turning Tabuk‚Äôs mountains and deserts into white landscapes/Image: X

'Israel Source Of Instability': Oman Leader Defends Iran, Blames Tel Aviv For Middle East Unrest





For the first time in three decades, snow has graced parts of Saudi Arabia, turning desert-framed mountains into icy landscapes and surprising residents with a rare winter spectacle. From snow-capped peaks to desert plains dusted in white, the Kingdom experienced a weather event that many had only imagined.A cold air mass sweeping across northern Saudi Arabia brought rain, strong winds, and record-low temperatures, creating ideal conditions for snowfall. In areas near Tabuk, including Jabal Al Lawz and the Trojena highlands, temperatures fell to around -4¬∞C, allowing snow to settle at altitudes near 2,600 metres. Social media quickly filled with photos and videos showing the mountains blanketed in white, capturing the historic moment.Residents of Tabuk and Hail have embraced the rare weather, stepping outside to ski, play, and capture the snowy scenery. Videos shared online show adults enjoying skiing, children playing in the snow, and even camels wandering across snow-covered desert plains beneath dark, dramatic clouds, a surreal scene that quickly went viral.The snowfall turned parts of the Kingdom into an unexpected winter playground, blending the familiar desert landscapes with a temporary, magical layer of ice and snow.Alongside the snow, the cold wave brought widespread and persistent rainfall to several regions, reinforcing the impact of the inclement weather. For many, the combination of freezing temperatures, snow-capped mountains, and sudden, unexpected winter activities offered both excitement and disbelief, marking a rare and unforgettable moment in Saudi Arabia‚Äôs climate history.
Article Summary: Rare snowfall blankets Saudi Arabia for the first time in 30 years. Cold air mass brought rain, strong winds, and record-low temperatures. Social media filled with photos and videos showing the mountains blanketed in white. Videos shared online show adults enjoying skiing, children playing in the snow, and camels wandering across snow-covered desert plains.

Article Title: UAE Central Bank shut down Omda exchange after violations, imposes Dh10m fine
Article Text:
CBUAE cancels licence of Omda Exchange in major enforcement move / Image: File

Why was the licence revoked?

What does this mean for you?

Knowing that the CBUAE is actively monitoring and "pruning" the market of non-compliant players means you can have higher confidence in the remaining licensed exchange houses.

These regulations are designed to prevent scams, fraud, and the misuse of financial platforms. A cleaner system means fewer risks for your personal hard-earned money.

By enforcing these rules, the UAE remains a globally respected financial hub. This keeps exchange rates competitive and ensures that international banks continue to work smoothly with UAE-based institutions.





The Central Bank of the UAE (CBUAE) has taken decisive action against Omda Exchange, revoking its licence and striking the company‚Äôs name off the official register of licensed entities. The regulator also imposed a financial penalty of Dh10 million on the foreign exchange firm. This enforcement follows supervisory examinations that uncovered multiple breaches of UAE banking laws and regulations.The move was carried out under the Decretal Federal Law on the Central Bank and the Organisation of Financial Institutions and Activities, which gives the CBUAE the authority to regulate, supervise, and enforce compliance across financial institutions operating in the country.According to official statements and regulatory findings, the CBUAE‚Äôs examinations revealed that Omda Exchange failed to comply with core legal and regulatory requirements. While specific details of each breach have not been fully disclosed publicly, the Central Bank‚Äôs action fits a broader pattern of strict enforcement against exchange houses that fall short of Anti-Money Laundering (AML) and other compliance standards.The move underscores the bank‚Äôs mandate to ensure that financial service providers adhere to legal obligations and internal controls that safeguard the integrity of financial transactions in the UAE.You might wonder how a corporate fine affects the average resident sending money home. The impact is actually very positive for the "common man." When the Central Bank takes such strict action, it is working to ensure that every dirham you hand over at a counter is safe.This latest enforcement is part of a broader, ongoing trend. In recent months, we have seen the CBUAE impose various fines‚Äîranging from Dh2 million to over Dh100 million, on different financial entities. This consistent "watchful eye" is part of the UAE's commitment to aligning with international standards set by global bodies like the Financial Action Task Force (FATF).The Central Bank has stated that it will continue to ensure that all exchange houses, their owners, and their staff strictly abide by UAE laws.This isn't just about punishment; it‚Äôs about prevention. By maintaining a transparent and high-standard environment, the UAE ensures that its financial system remains one of the most stable and secure in the world for residents and investors alike
Article Summary: The Central Bank of the UAE (CBUAE) has taken decisive action against Omda Exchange, revoking its licence and striking the company‚Äôs name off the official register of licensed entities. The regulator also imposed a financial penalty of Dh10 million on the foreign exchange firm.

Article Title: Epstein files out: Trump referenced in some newly released docs; DOJ calls claims 'untrue'
Article Text:
DOJ Epstein BOMBSHELL: Trump Did This On Jet With ‚ÄòBestie‚Äô & A Woman... | 11k More Files Released





The US Justice Department released nearly 30,000 additional pages of documents linked to Jeffrey Epstein, marking the largest disclosure yet in the long-running investigation into the late financier and convicted sex offender. The files also contained many of mentions of US President Donald Trump, although it includes an email from a prosecutor pointing out the flights that Trump took on Epstein‚Äôs private jet during the 1990s.The Department of Justice said that some material includes ‚Äúuntrue and sensationalist claims‚Äù about Trump that were submitted to the FBI shortly before the 2020 election. The department said those allegations were unfounded and false, but the records were being made public in the interests of legal transparency, with protections in place for Epstein‚Äôs victims.Among nearly 30,000 pages of material is now available on the official Justice Department website.An FBI intake report dated October 27, 2020, records a tip from a former limousine driver. According to that report, the driver described a disturbing phone conversation he claimed he overheard in 1995 involving Trump and Epstein.The driver‚Äôs account says the woman later told him she had contacted police about what had occurred, and was then found dead in January 2000 by suicide.The details in the file are heavily redacted, and the authorities have made little to no determination about the allegations‚Äô credibility.In an accompanying statement on X on Tuesday, DOJ addressed the claims. Article Title: What is 'winter vomiting bug'? Why a new variant is driving a US surge?
Article Text:
Representative Image

Symptoms



Treatment







The highly contagious norovirus is spreading rapidly across the country as the year comes to a close, driven by a surging variant. This new wave of norovirus outbreaks coincides with nationwide spikes in flu, whooping cough, measles, and COVID.Sickness from norovirus, often referred to as the "winter vomiting disease" or "winter vomiting bug," could require medical attention or even hospitalisation for immunocompromised people, the elderly and children, Axios reported.Cases of norovirus have picked up in California in recent weeks as a new subvariant, GII.17, has triggered a spike, according to the Los Angeles Times. The San Francisco and Los Angeles areas saw massive climbs in cases. Michigan, New Jersey and North Carolina have also reported upticks, while Texas, Oklahoma, Colorado, Alabama, Montana and Wyoming have seen rising case numbers, per data from Epic Research.For the week ending on Dec. 9, the national positivity rate was 9.9%, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. It climbed to 12.11% for the week ending on Dec. 13.Norovirus is a contagious disease that causes inflammation of the stomach and intestines, leading to extreme cases of vomiting and diarrhoea, per the CDC.It is one of the top causes of vomiting and diarrhoea and has gained the nickname "extreme vomiting disease."Roughly 20 million people contract norovirus every year in the US, per Scientific American. Outbreaks attributed to GII.17 rose from 7.5% during the 2022‚Äì23 season to 75.4% in the 2024‚Äì25 season, according to CDC data. In the same period, outbreaks of the previous leading variant, GII.4, fell from nearly 49% to 10.7%.Two other major illnesses are still circulating during the holiday season. COVID cases are surging nationwide, with 31 states reporting infections that are growing or likely growing, many driven by the XFG Stratus variant. Experts have also warned of a new flu outbreak in Europe, caused by a version of H3N2 that emerged over the summer.Symptoms of norovirus typically begin 12 to 48 hours after infection and include diarrhoea, vomiting, nausea, stomach pain and dehydration. Fever or body aches are possible but remain uncommon.There is no specific treatment for norovirus, but symptoms generally resolve within one to three days, per the Cleveland Clinic. Health officials recommend drinking liquids and electrolytes, eating bland foods, washing hands thoroughly and disinfecting surfaces. Hand sanitiser alone is ineffective, and anyone who catches norovirus may wish to avoid preparing food for a few days to limit the spread.

Article Title: New H-1B rules won't make much difference if $100,000 fee remains, Indian-origin immigration attorney explains why

Four wage levels

Though the new H-1B rules, based on wage, will do away with the existing random lottery, it will not make much difference if the proposed fee of $100,000 remains, as companies will still think twice before hiring H-1Bs who now have a better chance of getting a higher wage in the new rules. Indian-origin attorney Rahul Reddy said this wage-based model assumes steady participation across wage levels and locations but the assumption becomes less reliable when combined with a proposed $100,000 fillinf fee for H-1B cases initiated from outside the US."Even if a role qualifies for a higher wage level and stronger lottery odds, the cost of entry changes employer behavior. At some point, employers stop asking what their chances are and start asking whether filing makes sense at all. Higher odds do not matter if demand falls. If overseas filings decline sharply, the pool shrinks, and projected selection percentages may no longer reflect real-world outcomes," Rahul Reddy said.Level I wage generally reflects entry-level roles with limited experience and supervision. Under the weighted system, a Level I registration enters the lottery once. A Level II wage, representing more experience and independent work, enters the pool twice.Level III wages, typically for advanced or specialized roles, enter three times. Level IV wages, associated with senior, highly skilled positions, enter the lottery four times.Each beneficiary is still counted only once toward the annual cap, but the number of entries affects the odds. So estimated chances of selection rise materially with wage level. Level IV roles may see selection probabilities exceeding 60 percent, Level III around the mid-40 percent range, while Level I roles experience a much lower likelihood. The lottery still involves chance, but it is no longer blind. When odds are multiplied, randomness gives way to weighting."This wage-based model assumes steady participation across wage levels and locations. That assumption becomes less reliable when combined with a proposed $100,000 filing fee for H-1B cases initiated from outside the United States. Even if a role qualifies for a higher wage level and stronger lottery odds, the cost of entry changes employer behavior," Reddy said."At some point, employers stop asking what their chances are and start asking whether filing makes sense at all. Hospital officials said at least eight people hurt in rain-related incidents were brought to the Civil Hospital.The rainfall, which began on Saturday, ended a prolonged dry spell in the Quetta valley, offering brief relief to drought-hit farmers. However, it also caused widespread disruption. Despite forecasts ruling out significant rainfall, showers intensified by noon, flooding roads, halting traffic and plunging large parts of Quetta into darkness after electricity supplies were suspended. Mobile networks were also disrupted, leaving residents without communication for hours.Low-lying neighbourhoods, particularly areas with mud houses and weak construction, were badly affected as rainwater entered homes.Heavy rainfall was reported across several districts, including Ziarat, Pishin, Kalat, Zhob, Mastung and Sibi, with power outages lasting for hours in many areas.Meanwhile, experts warned that Pakistan‚Äôs water-quality crisis is worsening. Speaking at a seminar organised by the Pakistan Institute of Development Economics (PIDE) in Islamabad, specialists said only 47 per cent of the population has access to safe drinking water, according to The Express Tribune.Dr Hifza Rasheed of the Pakistan Council of Research in Water Resources said per capita freshwater availability has dropped from 5,260 cubic metres in 1951 to below 1,000 cubic metres in 2024, placing Pakistan among water-scarce nations. Unsafe water, experts said, accounts for nearly 40 per cent of illnesses nationwide and contributes to tens of thousands of child deaths each year.
Article Summary: A passenger waggon skidded on a rain-soaked highway and collided with an oncoming truck in Balochistan. Five passengers sustained injuries, with two shifted to Quetta for critical care. Hospital officials said at least eight people hurt in rain-related incidents were brought to the Civil Hospital.

Article Title: ‚ÄòPrepare for street movement‚Äô: Imran Khan calls for nationwide protests after 17 years sentence; claims his lawyers were not heard in court
Article Text:
Representative image (Picture credit: ANI)

Ex-PM Imran Khan And Bushra Bibi Jailed For 17 Years In Toshakhana Gift Jewellery Case





Pakistan‚Äôs former Prime Minister Imran Khan has asked his supporters to prepare for nationwide protests and said he will challenge his conviction in the Islamabad High Court after he and his wife, Bushra Bibi, were sentenced to 17 years in prison in the Toshakhana-II corruption case on Saturday.Khan, who does not currently have access to his social media accounts, conveyed his message through his legal team.According to a post on X cited by Dawn, the Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf (PTI) founder said he had instructed Khyber Pakhtunkhwa Chief Minister Sohail Afridi to begin preparations for a mass street movement. ‚ÄúI have sent a message to [Khyber Pakhtunkhwa CM] Sohail Afridi to prepare for the street movement. The entire nation will have to rise for its rights,‚Äù Khan said.Reacting to the verdict, Khan said the decision did not come as a surprise and accused the court of acting in haste. ‚ÄúLike the baseless decisions and sentences of the last three years, the Toshakhana-II decision is also nothing new to me,‚Äù he said, adding that the ruling was delivered ‚Äúwithout any evidence‚Äù and that his legal team was ‚Äúnot even heard‚Äù, as reported by ANI.He confirmed that his lawyers had already been directed to move the high court against the sentence.PTI, in an official statement, described the verdict as ‚Äúblatantly unconstitutional, illegal‚Äù and an act of political victimisation, alleging that the conviction was meant to prolong Khan‚Äôs imprisonment.Addressing a press conference, PTI secretary general Salman Akram Raja quoted Khan as saying, ‚ÄúI am standing firm and resolute and will not seek an apology from anyone, come what may.‚ÄùThe case relates to allegations that a Bulgari jewellery set, worth over PKR 71 million and received from the Saudi Crown Prince, was undervalued.Khan and Bushra Bibi were convicted under sections linked to criminal breach of trust and corruption, as per ANI.The sentencing has sparked public debate across Pakistan. Quoted by ANI, residents and journalists in Lahore and Peshawar questioned the credibility of the ruling, with some alleging political motives and a lack of evidence, saying the verdict had further weakened public trust in the justice system and democratic institutions.
Article Summary: Imran Khan and his wife, Bushra Bibi, were sentenced to 17 years in prison in the Toshakhana-II corruption case on Saturday. Khan has asked his supporters to prepare for nationwide protests and said he will challenge his conviction in the Islamabad High Court. The case relates to allegations that a Bulgari jewellery set, worth over PKR 71 million, was undervalued.

Article Title: 'No embargo': Pakistan refutes visit restrictions on Imran Khan's sons; promises visa approval
Article Text:
Former PM Imran Khan (File photo)

‚ÄòMight Never See Him Again‚Äô: Imran Khan‚Äôs Sons Claim 'Psychological Torture' In Pak's Adiala Jail





NEW DELHI: The Pakistan government on Saturday clarified that there is "no embargo" on former prime minister Imran Khan 's sons meeting their incarcerated father if they travel to the country. The government official also said the brothers would be granted Pakistani visas should they wish to come and visit him.The statement came after reports suggested that authorities had imposed unannounced restrictions on visits to Imran Khan, claiming that some visitors were using the meetings to advance political agendas. Following these reports, members of his family and Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf (PTI) expressed concern about the conditions in which he is being held."There has been no embargo on Suleman Khan and Kasim Khan to meet their father, Imran Khan, at Adiala Jail, Rawalpindi," Interior state minister Talal Chaudhry told reporters.Suleman and Kasim, who currently live in London, are Khan‚Äôs sons from his first marriage to British TV personality Jemima Goldsmith.Chaudhry‚Äôs clarification comes days after the brothers told Sky News they fear they may never see their jailed father again.The brothers said they have not seen or spoken to the PTI founder, imprisoned since August 2023, for months, and voiced concerns about his safety and well-being.‚ÄúIf Suleman and Kasim apply for a Pakistani visa, we will give them. We will not stop them from meeting their father; therefore, the propaganda that the Pakistani government is creating hurdles in the meeting between father and sons should be stopped,‚Äù Chaudhry said.He also rejected reports that Khan is being kept in solitary confinement for 23 hours a day.In their interview, the brothers alleged that their father is being held in isolation, calling the conditions ‚Äúclear torture tactics.‚ÄùKhan, who has been in jail since August 2023, faces multiple cases filed against him since his ouster from power in April 2022.A United Nations special rapporteur has also warned that Khan is being held in conditions that may amount to inhuman or degrading treatment.In the interview, Kasim claimed Khan is confined to a cell measuring ‚Äúsix feet by eight inches,‚Äù barely large enough to stand.‚ÄúThey are not even allowing guards to speak to him because they want total isolation from any other person, just to try and break him. So it‚Äôs all very clear torture tactics,‚Äù he said.
Article Summary: Suleman and Kasim Khan are Imran Khan's sons from his first marriage. The brothers said they have not seen or spoken to the PTI founder, imprisoned since August 2023, for months. In their interview, the brothers alleged that their father is being held in isolation, calling the conditions ‚Äúclear torture tactics.

Article Title: 'Lenient' punishment: Ex-Pak PM Imran Khan, wife sentenced to 17 years in prison; over Rs 52 lakh fine imposed on each
Article Text:
‚ÄòMight Never See Him Again‚Äô: Imran Khan‚Äôs Sons Claim 'Psychological Torture' In Pak's Adiala Jail





NEW DELHI: A special court of Pakistan‚Äôs Federal Investigation Agency on Saturday sentenced former prime minister and Pakistan Tehreek-i-Insaf founder Imran Khan and his wife Bushra Bibi to 17 years of imprisonment each in the Toshakhana 2 corruption case, Dawn reported.The court also imposed a fine of Pakistani Rs 16.4 million (INR 52,39,524) on each of them. Failure to pay the fine will result in additional jail time, according to the law.Citing the court order copy, Dawn reported that the sentences took into account Imran Khan‚Äôs age and the fact that Bushra Bibi is a woman, resulting in what the court described as a ‚Äúlenient‚Äù punishment. ‚ÄúThis court, while passing sentences has considered the old age of Imran Ahmed Khan Niazi, as well as the fact that Bushra Imran Khan is a female. It is in consideration of both said factors that a lenient view has been taken in awarding lesser punishment,‚Äù the order said.The verdict was delivered by special judge central Shahrukh Arjumand during a hearing held at Rawalpindi‚Äôs Adiala jail, where Imran Khan is currently imprisoned.According to Dawn, the case relates to the alleged purchase of an expensive Bulgari jewellery set that was gifted to Imran Khan by the Saudi crown prince during an official visit in May 2021 and later acquired at a throwaway price.Imran Khan was sentenced to a total of 17 years in prison, including 10 years‚Äô rigorous imprisonment under sections 34 and 409 of the Pakistan Penal Code and seven years under Section 5(2) of the Prevention of Corruption Act. Bushra Bibi was awarded the same sentence under identical provisions.The court also granted the benefit of Section 382 B of the Criminal Procedure Code, which allows the period of detention already undergone to be considered while awarding the sentence.Following the verdict, lawyers representing Imran Khan and Bushra Bibi said they would challenge the decision before the high court.The two were indicted in the case in December last year. Dawn noted that earlier this year in October, both had denied the allegations, calling the case fabricated and politically motivated.As per Dawn, while recording his statement under Section 342 of the Criminal Procedure Code, Imran Khan rejected the prosecution‚Äôs narrative and said the case was ‚Äúmalicious, fabricated, and politically engineered‚Äù. He argued that he did not qualify as a public servant under the Pakistan Penal Code and claimed he was unaware of the specific details of the gift, which he said was presented to his wife.Dawn further reported that the PTI founder maintained that due process was followed under the Toshakhana Policy 2018 and that the gift was declared, assessed and legally retained after payment to the national exchequer. ‚ÄúWe complied with the Toshakhana Policy in letter and spirit,‚Äù he said.
Article Summary: Imran Khan and his wife Bushra Bibi sentenced to 17 years of imprisonment each in corruption case. The court also imposed a fine of Pakistani Rs 16.4 million (INR 52,39,524) on each of them. Failure to pay the fine will result in additional jail time, according to the law.

Article Title: Pakistan: Former PM Imran Khan's sisters, supporters booked under anti-terrorism law; 14 arrested
Article Text:
Aleema Khan

‚ÄòMight Never See Him Again‚Äô: Imran Khan‚Äôs Sons Claim 'Psychological Torture' In Pak's Adiala Jail





Pakistan police on Wednesday registered a case under the Anti-Terrorism Act against the sisters of former prime minister Imran Khan and dozens of his supporters after a protest sit-in outside Adiala Jail in Rawalpindi.The protest on Tuesday was held after authorities refused to allow family members and lawyers to meet Khan, who is currently incarcerated. His sisters, along with leaders and workers of the Pakistan Tehreek-i-Insaf (PTI), staged the sit-in outside the jail to protest the restriction.Police said a first information report (FIR) was lodged at Police Station Saddar Beroni, Rawalpindi, naming Khan‚Äôs sisters Aleema Khan and Noreen Niazi, as well as several PTI leaders and supporters. Those named include Salman Akram Raja, Naeem Panjotha, Qasim Khan, Aliya Hamza and Raja Nasir Abbas.Authorities also invoked Section 120 of the Pakistan Penal Code for alleged criminal conspiracy against the state, along with charges of attacking police personnel and violating Section 144.Police said, as reported by PTI, at least 14 suspects were arrested at the scene late Tuesday night, and efforts are continuing to arrest others named in the FIR.Imran Khan has been in jail since August 2023 and faces multiple cases filed after his removal from office in April 2022.Officials have placed restrictions on meetings with Khan, saying such visits are being used for political purposes. The last meeting with him took place on December 2, when his sister Uzma Khan was allowed to see him.
Article Summary: Police register a case against the sisters of former prime minister Imran Khan and dozens of his supporters after a protest sit-in outside Adiala Jail in Rawalpindi. The protest was held after authorities refused to allow family members and lawyers to meet Khan, who is currently incarcerated.

Article Title: Still afloat, still fragile: How Pakistan economy is dodging a complete collapse ‚Äî explained
Article Text:
Quetta, Pakistan (AP file photo)

IMF‚Äôs New Conditions Expose Pakistan‚Äôs Deep Economic Faultlines Amid $7 Billion Rescue Package

(Source: IMF)

What is keeping Pakistan afloat

IMF support: Pakistan's key lifeline

(Source: IMF)

Tactical monetary management

Signs of financial market confidence

Tentative re-engagement with US

Deepening strategic and economic ties with China

The structural weaknesses holding Pakistan back

IMF's diagnosis of 'state capture' and 'elite privilege'

'Diagnosis is familiar, implementation is not'

Transparency concerns in federal structure

World Bank warning: stability without prosperity

India's decision to suspend IWT

(PTI file photo)

Operation Sindoor and security spillovers

Afghanistan's dams ‚Äî a second, converging shock

Survival without transformation





How is Pakistan‚Äôs economy still surviving? The question continues to arise as the country grapples with prolonged economic stress despite years of weak growth and low human development indicators.In recent years, Pakistan has dealt with sharp currency swings, runaways inflation between 2022 and 2024, persistent balance-of-payments pressures and mounting external debt burden. Yet the economy has managed to dodge a complete collapse, largely due to repeated bailouts from the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and emergency financing from external partners.China has been key to this survival. Chinese loans and infrastructure investments have provided short-term relief but have also deepened Islamabad's financial dependence on Beijing. At the same time, Pakistan has sought to rebuild ties with the United States, long regarded as a key economic and diplomatic backstop.In this outreach, both army chief Asim Munir, now seen as the Pakistan's de facto power centre, and Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif have taken apparent steps to engage Washington. The two leaders went ahead to nominate US President Donald Trump for the Nobel Peace Prize, citing his role in easing military tensions with India.However, New Delhi had turned down the claims of any foreign influence in peaceful agreement with Islamabad in May this year.And Uncle Sam responded with goodwill. Compared to several other countries, it was exempted from steep trade tariffs, with Washington announcing a lower levy of 19%. Trump has also spoken of possible cooperation in developing what he described as "massive oil reserves" in Pakistan.The power structure in Pakistan has also been a point of concern in its economic turmoil. The military's expanding role in governance has often overshadowed the civilian leadership, while former prime minister and a popular leader Imran Khan remains in prison, keeping political tensions high and weighing on investor confidence.Neighbouring countries have also added to Pakistan‚Äôs economic strain. India‚Äôs suspension of the Indus Waters Treaty has emerged as a major setback, while Afghanistan‚Äôs Taliban government has announced plans to build dams upstream, moves that could further affect water availability and pose another risk to Pakistan‚Äôs economy and GDP growth.For now, Pakistan‚Äôs economy continues to function through foreign assistance, administrative controls and short-term stabilisation measures. Without sustained political stability, meaningful reforms and an effective check on corruption, its economic survival remains fragile.One of the most important stabilisers of Pakistan's economy has been the continued support from the International Monetary Fund and other multilateral lenders.The Governance and Corruption Diagnostic Assessment (GCDA) finalised in November 2025, was released ahead of the Fund's executive board's expected approval of a $1.2 billion disbursement, part of the ongoing 37-month, $7 billion programme started under the prime ministership of Shehbaz Sharif.With the latest approval, Pakistan has received around $3.3 billion from the IMF since last year. Under the bailout programme, Islamabad will continue to receive loan instalments over a 37-month period, contingent on meeting the agreed reform conditions.Pakistan narrowly avoided default in 2023 only after the IMF extended an earlier nine-month emergency deal, which was followed by the current longer programme. Since 1958, Pakistan has turned to the IMF 25 times, making it one of the IMF's most frequent borrowers.In 2025, IMF disbursements helped rebuild foreign exchange buffers, reassure markets and finance imports and debt servicing, according to Reuters.Pakistan's central bank has used monetary policy as a tactical tool to stabilise inflation while cautiously supporting growth.On December 15, the State Bank of Pakistan cut its key interest rate by 50 basis points to 10.5%, breaking a four-meeting hold. The SBP said the move was aimed at supporting sustainable economic growth while keeping inflation within target.According to Reuters, all 12 analysts in a Reuters poll had expected the central bank to hold the policy rate at 11%, particularly after the IMF warned against premature easing under Pakistan's $7 billion loan programme.The rate cut highlighted Pakistan's effort to revive domestic economic activity without destabilising the IMF-backed stabilisation framework.Despite underlying weaknesses, Pakistan has seen improving sentiment in financial markets.Credit ratings agencies S&P Global, Fitch and Moody‚Äôs upgraded Pakistan‚Äôs credit ratings in 2025, citing stronger finances and revenue gains. Investor appetite for Pakistan‚Äôs dollar bonds and equities has strengthened, with bonds delivering nearly 22% returns this year and the benchmark stock index gaining 44%, among the best performers in Asia.Bloomberg Economics estimates growth quickened to 3.4% year-on-year in the second quarter, with official data expected shortly.However, with the backdrop of political chaos, most notably the continued imprisonment of the country's most popular political figure, Imran Khan, investors have little confidence to make long-term plans in Pakistan.Pakistan has also moved to rebuild economic ties with the United States.According to Bloomberg, Islamabad is planning an investor conference in Washington to draw American investment in energy, mining and technology. Finance minister Muhammad Aurangzeb said the sectors where Pakistan seeks US investment are clearly identified.Economic links have improved following a new US-Pakistan trade deal setting a 19% tariff, lower than regional peers and well below the 50% tariff imposed on India.Meanwhile, Trump also promised to help Pakistan develop what he described as "massive oil reserves" on Pakistani soil. The remarks followed sustained praise and outreach from Pakistan‚Äôs de facto power centre, army chief Asim Munir, and were later echoed by Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif, who went on to nominate Trump for the Nobel Peace Prize on several occasions.‚ÄúThe first thing was to get the trade equation out of the way, which it is now,‚Äù Aurangzeb told Bloomberg."Every single industry in Pakistan has to have an export component, because it‚Äôs the only way we're going to get out of this boom-and-bust cycle," Aurangzeb added.Beyond Western partners, Pakistan continues to rely heavily on China.According to the Middle East Institute, Pakistan‚Äôs strategic reliance on Beijing has deepened, particularly through the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC). In January, Dawn reported that Pakistan and China reaffirmed their commitment to high-quality development of CPEC 2.0, focusing on industrialisation, special economic zones, clean energy, agriculture and livelihood projects.Chinese support has provided Pakistan with infrastructure investment, energy projects and diplomatic backing at moments of economic stress.While IMF financing has stabilised Pakistan, the IMF's own assessment paints a deeply troubling picture of governance in the Islamic Republic.The IMF's Governance and Corruption Diagnostic Assessment concluded that corruption in Pakistan is driven by "state capture", where public policy is manipulated to benefit a narrow circle of political and business elites.The 186-page report described dysfunctional institutions unable to enforce the rule of law or protect public resources. Corruption, the IMF said, is persistent and corrosive, distorting markets, eroding public trust and undermining fiscal stability.The report warns that without dismantling entrenched structures of elite privilege, Pakistan‚Äôs economic stagnation will persist.According to the IMF, the most economically damaging corruption involves privileged entities that exert influence over key economic sectors, including those owned by or affiliated with the state.Stefan Dercon, a professor of economic policy at the University of Oxford who has advised Pakistan on reforms, told Al Jazeera that lack of accountability continues to erode economic potential."Failure of implementation [of laws and principles of accountability] gives vested interests too often free rein and addressing this must be at the core of efforts for economic reform," Dercon said.Ali Hasanain, associate professor of economics at the Lahore University of Management Sciences, said the IMF‚Äôs findings mirror long-standing domestic research."The IMF diagnostic repeats what many domestic studies, including those by the World Bank and Pakistan‚Äôs own institutions, have already emphasised: Powerful interests shape rules to maintain their advantage," Hasanain told Al Jazeera.A 2021 UNDP report found that economic privileges granted to Pakistan‚Äôs elite, including politicians and the powerful military, amount to roughly 6 percent of GDP.The IMF report also flags governance risks linked to the Special Investment Facilitation Council (SIFC), created in June 2023 to promote investment and comprising both civilian and military leaders.The GCDA raises concerns over broad legal immunity granted to SIFC officials and the council‚Äôs authority to exempt projects from regulatory requirements.‚ÄúThe recently established Special Investment Facilitation Council, which has been vested with substantial authority to facilitate foreign investments, operates with untested transparency and accountability provisions,‚Äù the IMF report said.The Fund urged greater transparency, including annual public reporting on investments facilitated and concessions granted.The World Bank has warned that macroeconomic stabilisation has not translated into meaningful improvements in living standards."Business as usual is not good for the economy," said Mukhtar Ul Hasan, World Bank economist and lead author of a report on Pakistan."Pakistan's growth potential has been declining for decades" due to weak competitiveness, limited reforms and recurring crises, he added.The World Bank projects growth of 3% this year and 3.4% next year, far below what is needed to absorb 1.6 million new labour market entrants annually.The Bank‚Äôs poverty and resilience report shows poverty rising again to over 27% by 2023‚Äì24, with nearly half the population living below the lower-middle-income poverty line. Rural areas, especially Balochistan and interior Sindh, face far greater deprivation.Geopolitics has added new economic risks.After a Pakistan-sponsored terror attack in Jammu and Kashmir‚Äôs Pahalgam that killed 26 civilians, India answered strongly to its misadventure by putting the Indus Waters Treaty in abeyance. Islamabad responded by warning that any attempt to stop or divert water flows would be treated as an "act of war."Around 80% of Pakistani farms depend on the Indus system, as do nearly all hydropower projects. India had also identified hydropower projects in Jammu and Kashmir that could expand capacity to 12,000 MW from the current 3,360 MW, according to Reuters.In May 2025 India‚Äôs crossborder counterterror action under Operation Sindoor, marked a sharp escalation in India-Pakistan security dynamics. Military operations and reciprocal measures elevate defence spending, crowd out development spending, spook investors, and raise insurance and logistics costs for trade.Pakistan suffered a major setback after Indian strikes severely damaged nine of its key airbases, including Nur Khan and Rahim Yar Khan, dealing a significant blow to its military infrastructure.Pakistan‚Äôs economic capacity has been heavily drained by sustained military expenditure driven by its adversarial policies toward India, a burden that has come at the cost of investment in social sectors and has pushed the country down across multiple human development indicators.Reports indicate Afghanistan's new dam projects on rivers that feed Pakistan (Kunar/Kabul tributaries) will further diminish cross-border flows into Pakistan‚Äôs north-west. Combined with India‚Äôs measures, this convergence would be a "double blast" to Pakistani water security ‚Äî concentrated in already drought-prone provinces that supply major agricultural output.Reduced river flows affect irrigation, livelihoods and hydroelectricity; they also fuel internal migration pressures and raise the social cost of adjustment. Regional cooperation mechanisms for water management have weakened, making unilateral upstream development a direct economic shock for downstream Pakistan.Pakistan‚Äôs economy is surviving due to IMF support, tactical policy moves, selective foreign investment and geopolitical manoeuvring, including heavy dependence on China and US.But without deep structural reform, dismantling elite privilege and restoring institutional accountability, survival may continue without delivering broad-based prosperity, leaving the country trapped in the same cycle of crisis and rescue that has defined its economic history.
Article Summary: Pakistan narrowly avoided default in 2023 only after the IMF extended an earlier nine-month emergency deal. Since 1958, Pakistan has turned to the IMF 25 times, making it one of the IMF's most borrowers. Without sustained political stability, meaningful reforms and an effective check on corruption, Pakistan's economic survival remains fragile.
